(UK series 17)]]'' | signature = | website = {{official website|http://www.shappi.co.uk/}} | footnotes = | module = | parents = [[Hadi Khorsandi]] (father) }} '''Shaparak''' "'''Shappi'''" '''Khorsandi''' ({{lang-fa|شاپرک خرسندی}}, born 8 June 1973{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ShappiKhorsandi/status/15442975410 |title=Twitter / Shappi Khorsandi: It's my birthday on Tuesday |publisher=Twitter |date=4 June 2010 |accessdate=26 January 2011}}{{Primary source inline|date=December 2017}}) is a British{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ShappiKhorsandi/status/231861374672850945|title=Shappi Khorsandi on Twitter|work=Twitter|accessdate=30 May 2015}}{{Primary source inline|date=December 2017}} comedian and author of Iranian origin. The daughter of the Iranian political satirist and poet [[Hadi Khorsandi]], her family left [[Iran]] when she was a child following the [[Islamic Revolution]]. In January 2016, she became president of the [[British Humanist Association]] (now known as Humanists UK).{{Cite web|url=https://www.thebookseller.com/news/khorsandis-debut-novel-ebury-307960|title=Khorsandi's debut novel to Ebury {{!}} The Bookseller|website=www.thebookseller.com|access-date=24 November 2017}} Her second book and first novel, ''Nina is Not OK'', was released in 2016. == Background and personal life == The daughter of [[Hadi Khorsandi]], she was born in Iran and says her earliest memory is 'riding on a bicycle in Tehran, on my uncle's lap at dawn, to get chocolate milk'.{{cite web|last1=Lisa|first1=Williams|title=Shappi Khorsandi: How I Was Raised|url=https://tantrum.xyz/posts/shappi_khorsandi_how_i_was_raised_164|website=TantrumXYZ|publisher=TantrumXYZ|accessdate=18 July 2016}} She and her family were forced to flee from Iran to London after the [[Islamic Revolution]] following the publication of a satirical poem her father composed. The poem was seen as critical of the revolutionary regime. Khorsandi was raised without any religion,{{cite web |url=http://newhumanist.org.uk/1514 |title=Diary: Comic timing |author= Shappi Khorsandi|date=January–February 2007 |work=New Humanist:Articles, Volume 122 Issue 1 |publisher=The Rationalist Association |accessdate=25 March 2010}} and identifies as an [[atheist]] and a [[secular humanism|humanist]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/aug/10/shappi-khorsandi-last-laugh|title=Shappi Khorsandi: the last laugh|author=Charlotte Higgins|work=The Guardian|accessdate=30 May 2015}} She later became a Patron of the [[British Humanist Association]], which appointed her as its President from January 2016, succeeding [[Jim Al-Khalili]].{{cite web|url = https://humanism.org.uk/2015/12/14/shappi-khorsandi-named-new-president-of-the-british-humanist-association/|title = Shappi Khorsandi named new President of the British Humanist Association|work = British Humanist Association|accessdate = 14 December 2015}} Khorsandi graduated from King Alfred's College, now the [[University of Winchester]], in 1995, with a degree in Drama, Theatre and television, then moved on to pursue a career in comedy. In 2010, the university awarded her an honorary doctorate.{{cite web |url=http://www.winchester.ac.uk/newsandevents/Pages/ComedianShappiKhorsanditobehonouredbytheUniversityofWinchester.aspx|title=Comedian Shappi Khorsandi to be honoured by the University of Winchester|publisher= The University of Winchester|date=5 October 2010|accessdate=19 August 2012}} Khorsandi was married to fellow comedian Christian Reilly, with whom she has a son, Cassius.{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/my-perfect-weekend/7741805/My-perfect-weekend-Shappi-Khorsandi.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Bertan | last=Budak | title=My perfect weekend: Shappi Khorsandi | date=21 May 2010}} They divorced in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghampost.co.uk/whats-on/comedy-news/comedian-shappi-khorsandi-heads-west-7048292|title=Comedian Shappi Khorsandi heads to the West Midlands for a run of shows – Birmingham Post|author=Roz Laws|date=2 May 2014|work=birminghampost|accessdate=30 May 2015}} Khorsandi lives with her son in South-West London near [[Richmond Park]]. Her father and brother are also stand-up comedians.Video interview of Khorsandi on [[Carpool (web series)|Carpool]] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rL8V_VWMWT8 In November 2012, she announced on Twitter that she was expecting her second child, due in the summer of 2013. On 7 June 2013, Khorsandi gave birth to a baby girl, Genevieve. In a 2014 interview she said "I’m doing it all on my own, I have no contact with the father. But that’s fine, I’m not angry or bitter." She identifies as [[bisexuality|bisexual]].{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/punching-ups/2017/08/18/37573/shappi_khorsandi%3A_im_bisexual|title=Shappi Khorsandi: I'm bisexual.|work=Chortle|accessdate=6 September 2017|date=18 August 2017}} == Career == [[File:Shappi Khorsandi 02.JPG|thumb|upright|Shappi Khorsandi at Glastonbury Festival 2015]] Khorsandi performs comedy, having been a noted performer at Joe Wilson's Comedy Madhouse throughout 1997. She has appeared on many [[BBC Radio 4]] programmes, including ''[[Quote... Unquote]]'', ''[[Loose Ends (radio)|Loose Ends]]'', ''[[You and Yours]]'', ''Midweek'', ''[[Just A Minute]]'', ''[[The Now Show]]'' and ''[[The News Quiz]]'', as well as [[BBC Television]]'s ''[[Have I Got News For You]]'' and ''[[QI]]''. In July 2009, she hosted her own four-part series, ''Shappi Talk'' on [[BBC Radio 4]], examining what it is like growing up in multi-cultural families.{{cite web|author= – 22:45 |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00lh4z0 |title=Radio 4 Programmes – Shappi Talk: Series 1 |publisher=BBC |date=19 October 2010 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} She also writes an occasional column for online magazine [[Iranian.com]]. In 2007, Khorsandi made her first trip to Australia and the [[Melbourne Comedy Festival]] with her show ''Asylum Speaker''. She also appeared live on the Australia comedy talk show ''Rove''. Later, she was nominated for best breakthrough act at the 2007 Chortle Awards. In December 2008, she appeared on the BBC stand-up television show ''[[Live at the Apollo (TV series)|Live at the Apollo]]'' alongside [[Russell Kane]] and [[Al Murray]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00fyjm0 |title=BBC listing |publisher=BBC |accessdate=26 January 2011}} She also made an appearance on ''[[Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow]]'' on 20 June 2009, ''[[Friday Night with Jonathan Ross]]'' on 26 June 2009 and ''[[8 Out of 10 Cats]]'' on 10 July 2009. Khorsandi's memoir, ''A Beginner's Guide to Acting English'', was published by [[Ebury Press]] on 2 July 2009.{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org.uk/events_details.asp?ID=1258 |title=A Beginner's Guide to Acting English |publisher=Amnesty.org.uk |accessdate=26 January 2011}} She performed her show, ''The Distracted Activist'', at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] from 6 to 31 August 2009.{{cite web|url=http://edinburghfestival.list.co.uk/event/10000248-shappi-khorsandi-the-distracted-activist/ |title=Shappi Khorsandi: The Distracted Activist | Edinburgh Festival Guide |publisher=Edinburghfestival.list.co.uk |date=21 August 2009 |accessdate=26 January 2011}} Khorsandi was a panellist on ''[[Question Time (TV series)|Question Time]]'' in 2006, and returned on 14 January 2010. During that show, she mentioned that she supports [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]]. She performed on the second episode of ''[[Let's Dance for Comic Relief#Heat Two 2|Let's Dance for Sport Relief 2010]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/letsdance/news/2010/news250210.shtml|title=Who will be competing on Show two?|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2 March 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/letsdance/news/2010/news270210.shtml|title=Show Two Report|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2 March 2010}} In 2010, Khorsandi took part in ''[[Channel 4's Comedy Gala]]'', a [[Benefit concert|benefit show]] held in aid of [[Great Ormond Street Hospital|Great Ormond Street Children's Hospital]], filmed live at the [[The O2 Arena (London)|O2 Arena]] in London on 30 March. She appeared as a guest in ''[[Genius (UK TV series)|Genius]]'' hosted by [[Dave Gorman]] on 31 October 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/genius/episodes/2/6/ |title=Genius With Dave Gorman – Episode 2.6. Noddy Holder and Shappi Khorsandi – British Comedy Guide |publisher=Comedy.co.uk |accessdate=26 January 2011}} In March 2012, Khorsandi appeared on Channel 4's ''[[The Bank Job (game show)|The Celebrity Bank Job]]'' and won £59,000 for her chosen charities. Khorsandi is a member of [[the Arts Emergency Service]], a British charity working with 16- to 19-year-olds in [[further education]] from diverse backgrounds.{{cite web|url=http://e-activist.com/ea-action/action?ea.client.id=1789&ea.campaign.id=23045|title=Media Diversity UK|publisher=E-activist.com |accessdate=25 October 2013}} On 19 and 20 November 2014, Khorsandi was a guest panellist on ''[[Loose Women]]'', filling in for [[Jamelia]]. She appeared on ''The Blame Game'' on [[BBC Northern Ireland]] hosted by [[Tim McGarry]] on 5 December 2014.{{Cite web|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b04t0mz6/the-blame-game-series-8-episode-6#group=p02bs34c|title = The Blame Game|date = 5 December 2014|accessdate = 12 December 2014|publisher = BBC Iplayer}} In 2016, Khorsandi appeared with her son on ''[[Big Star's Little Star]]''. Also in 2016, along with numerous other celebrities, Khorsandi toured the UK to support [[Jeremy Corbyn]]'s bid to become [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]].{{cite web |url=http://www.jc4pmtour.com/|title=#JC4PM|publisher=jc4pmtour|date=28 July 2015|accessdate=15 July 2017}}{{cite news |last=Wilkinson|first=Michael|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/Jeremy_Corbyn/12134051/Celebrities-to-tour-Britain-in-Jeremy-Corbyn-For-Prime-Minister-musical-show.html|title=Celebrities to tour Britain in 'Jeremy Corbyn For Prime Minister' musical show|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=1 February 2016|accessdate=15 July 2017}} In November 2017, Khorsandi appeared as a contestant on the seventeenth series of ''[[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (UK TV series)|I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!]]'' and was placed 11th in the competition.{{Cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/imacelebrity/celebrities/meet-your-2017-celebrity-campmates|title=Meet your 2017 Celebrity Campmates!|access-date=24 November 2017}} ==''A Beginner's Guide to Acting English''== The book describes the way in which Khorsandi experienced England as a young girl. The narrative begins with her attending nursery school, The Kings' International Nursery School, with her brother, Peyvand. Throughout the book, she explains the ways in which the Persian language differs from English: "They called me ‘poppet’. Iranians said 'jaan' or 'azizam'." She also expresses pride in how her father took English classes and was praised for his affinity with the written word, though she also felt he was able to be more humorous in [[Persian language|Persian]]. Other themes include her experiences with English food and customs, the war between Iran and Iraq, and the hostilities that she and her family encounter—she notes, for example, having been referred to as a terrorist. ==See also== *[[Iranian stand-up comedy]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Shappi Khorsandi}} {{wikiquote}} *{{official website|http://www.shappi.co.uk/}} *{{IMDb name|2161726}} *[http://www.comedycv.co.uk/shappikhorsandi/ Shappi Khorsandi] at Comedy CV *[http://www.iranian.com/shappi.html Shappi's Diary] at [[Iranian.com]] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/4760066.stm Iranian diaspora: Shappi Khorsandi] at [[BBC News Online]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070403164524/http://www.comedyfestival.com.au/season/2007/show/402/ Shappi Khorsandi] at [[Melbourne Comedy Festival]] *[http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/s/412/shappi_khorsandi Chortle account] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Khorsandi, Shappi}} [[Category:1973 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Winchester]] [[Category:Bisexual women]] [[Category:British stand-up comedians]] [[Category:British women comedians]] [[Category:Comedians from London]] [[Category:People from Ealing]] [[Category:British atheists]] [[Category:British humanists]] [[Category:British women novelists]] [[Category:British women comedians]] [[Category:Iranian emigrants to the United Kingdom]] [[Category:LGBT comedians]] [[Category:LGBT people from Iran]] [[Category:LGBT entertainers from the United Kingdom]] [[Category:People from Tehran]] [[Category:BBC 100 Women]] [[Category:20th-century British comedians]] [[Category:21st-century British comedians]] [[Category:Labour Party (UK) people]]
